user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_:
```c
bool
MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_ (struct MHD_Response *response,
                                  enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                                  char *header,
                                  size_t header_len,
                                  char *content,
                                  size_t content_len)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *hdr;

  mhd_assert (0 != header_len);
  mhd_assert (0 != content_len);
  if (NULL == (hdr = MHD_calloc_ (1, sizeof (struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header))))
    return false;

  hdr->header = header;
  hdr->header_size = header_len;
  hdr->value = content;
  hdr->value_size = content_len;
  hdr->kind = kind;
  _MHD_insert_header_last (response, hdr);

  return true; /* Success exit point */
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_:
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
...
#define MHD_calloc_(n, s) calloc((n),(s))
...
#define _MHD_insert_header_last(presponse, phdr) do{mhd_assert(NULL==phdr->next);mhd_assert(NULL==phdr->prev);if(NULL==presponse->last_header){mhd_assert(NULL==presponse->first_header);presponse->last_header=phdr;presponse->first_header=phdr;}else{mhd_assert(NULL!=presponse->first_header);presponse->last_header->next=phdr;phdr->prev=presponse->last_header;presponse->last_header=phdr;}\
}while(0)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (NULL == (hdr = MHD_calloc_ (1, sizeof (struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header))))
    return false;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No — as written this fragment does not create unreachable code. The conditional return is a legitimate runtime check: if calloc fails (hdr == NULL) the function returns false; otherwise execution continues. Given the supplied macro MHD_calloc_ maps to calloc, both outcomes are possible and reachable. (A possible violation scenario would be if MHD_calloc_ were implemented to never return NULL — e.g. it aborts or terminates the program on allocation failure — in which case the return false branch would be unreachable and would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1.)
